title: Judge jails rapist for just three years - because he handed himself in to police
text:
Matthew West called the police to admit his guilt although his victim did not report his crime (Photo: Derby Telegraph / SWNS) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
A rapist was jailed for just three years - after a judge gave him 'credit' for calling police to confess his vile crime. 
Matthew West, 24, was told how he “robbed the girl of her autonomy in the most intimate of ways” when he raped her in her home in January 2015. 
After the disgusting act West apologised to his victim and admitted: “I was a rapist.” 
However, the fact that he called the police to own up to the offence, coupled with a history of mental health issues, led to a reduced sentence . 
West, of Derby, pleaded guilty to one count of rape. 
Sentencing him at Derby Crown Court today, Judge Peter Cooke said: “This would never have come to court had you not picked up the phone and called 999. Read More Sex attacker caught after detective scoured database of 38,000 shoe soles to match footprint left at scene Matthew West pleaded guilty to one count of rape at Derby Crown Court (Photo: Google Maps) 
“The knowledge of what you had done and the guilt you felt made you make that call and that merits significant credit. 
“It is rare that a rape will result in a sentence such as this but this is an unusual case. You climbed on top of this woman and she told you to get off. 
“She kept saying ‘no’ but you carried on anyway. You even described yourself to her as a rapist.” 
The victim, who cannot be named, did not report to the crime to the police. 
However, on March 25 2015, West picked up the phone and admitted his crime to the police. Read More 
Prosecutor Andrew Vout said: “She kept saying ‘No, no. no’ but the defendant carried on and he raped her. She was crying and kept telling him to get off.’ 
“When it was over he said he was sorry and said to her ‘I was a rapist’. 
“It was a 999 call from the defendant saying he wanted to hand himself in because he had raped a woman. 
“Both he and the victim were visited by the police and the victim confirmed that she had been raped by the defendant. 
“In his interview, the defendant gave the same account to the police.” 
Tony Stanford, defending, said: “The most powerful mitigation is that he was the person that shopped himself in and was full and frank about what he did. 
“He is a person who has considerable family support and whose older brother says he will attempt to be good influence on his younger brother when he is released from custody.” Like us on Facebook
